translation: Now the word of the LORD came to Jonah son of Amittai, saying,
Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry out against it, for their evil has come up before Me.

But Jonah rose to flee to Tarshish from the presence of the LORD, and he went down to Joppa and found a ship coming to Tarshish; and he paid its fare and went down into it, to go with them to Tarshish, away from the presence of the LORD.
But the LORD hurled a great wind upon the sea, and there arose a mighty tempest on the sea, so that the ship thought it would be broken apart.

Then the sailors were afraid, and each cried out to his god, and they hurled the cargo that was in the ship into the sea to lighten it from upon them. But Jonah had gone down into the innermost parts of the vessel, and he lay down and fell into a deep sleep.
And the captain came near to him and said to him, What is it to you, O sleeper? Arise, call upon your God; perhaps the God will give thought to us, that we do not perish.
And they said each to his companion, Come, and let us cast lots, that we may know for whose cause this evil is upon us. So they cast lots, and the lot fell upon Jonah.
And they said to me, “Tell us now, on whose account this evil is upon us. What is your occupation, and from where do you come? What is your country, and of what people are you?”
And he said to them, I am a Hebrew, and I fear the LORD, the God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land.

Then the men were seized with a great fear, and they said to him, “What is this that you have done?” For the men knew that from before the presence of the LORD he was fleeing, because he had told them.
Then they said to him, What shall we do to you, that the sea may be calm for us? For the sea was going and raging ever more.
And he said to them, “Lift me up and cast me into the sea, and the sea will be calm for you, for I know that it is on my account that this great storm is upon you.”
But the men rowed hard to bring the ship back to the dry land, yet they could not, for the sea went on raging against them.
And they cried to the LORD and said, “We beg you, O LORD, let us not perish for this man’s life, and do not lay upon us innocent blood; for you, O LORD, have done as it pleased you.”
So they lifted up Jonah and hurled him into the sea, and the sea ceased from its raging.
Then the men feared the LORD with a great fear, and they offered a sacrifice to the LORD and made vows.
And the LORD appointed a great fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.
And Jonah prayed to the LORD his God from the belly of the fish.
I called out of my distress to the LORD, and He answered me; out of the belly of Sheol I cried for help; You heard my voice.
For you cast me into the deep, into the heart of the seas, and the current surrounded me; all your breakers and your waves passed over me.
And I said, I am driven away from before Your eyes; yet I will again look toward Your holy temple.
Waters encompassed me to the soul; the deep surrounded me; reeds were bound about my head.
To the roots of the mountains I went down; the earth with its bars was around me forever. Yet You brought up my life from the pit, O LORD my God.
When my soul fainted within me, I remembered the LORD, and my prayer came to You, into Your holy temple.
Those who regard lying vanities forsake their own mercy.
But as for me, with the voice of thanksgiving I will sacrifice to You; what I have vowed I will pay. Salvation belongs to the LORD.
And the LORD spoke to the fish, and it vomited Jonah out upon the dry land.
And the word of the LORD came to Jonah a second time, saying,
Arise, go to Nineveh, the great city, and proclaim to it the proclamation that I am speaking to you.
So Jonah arose and went to Nineveh, according to the word of the LORD. Now Nineveh was an exceedingly great city to God, a journey of three days.
And Jonah began to enter into the city a day’s journey, and he cried out and said, Yet forty days, and Nineveh shall be overthrown.
And the men of Nineveh believed in God, and they proclaimed a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them even to the least of them.
And the word reached the king of Nineveh, and he arose from his throne, and laid aside his robe from upon him, and covered himself with sackcloth, and sat upon the ashes.

And he caused it to be proclaimed and said in Nineveh, by decree of the king and his great ones, saying, Let neither man nor beast, herd nor flock, taste anything; let them not feed, and let them not drink water.
And let man and beast be covered with sackcloth, and let them cry mightily to God; and let each turn from his evil way, and from the violence that is in their hands.
Who knows? God may turn and relent, and turn from the fierceness of His anger, so that we do not perish.
And God saw their works, that they turned from their evil way; and God relented of the evil which He had spoken to do to them, and He did not do it.
But it was a great evil to Jonah, and he burned with anger.

And he prayed to the LORD and said, “Please, O LORD, was not this my word while I was yet in my own land? Therefore I made haste to flee to Tarshish; for I knew that you are a gracious and compassionate God, slow to anger and abundant in lovingkindness, and relenting from the calamity.”
And now, O LORD, take, I pray, my life from me, for my death is better to me than my life.
And the LORD said, Is it well for you to be so angry?
Then Jonah went out from the city and sat on the east side of the city, and there he made for himself a booth and sat under it in the shade, till he might see what would become of the city.
And the LORD God appointed a plant, and it came up over Jonah, to be a shade over his head, to deliver him from his misery. And Jonah rejoiced over the plant with exceedingly great joy.
But God appointed a worm, when the dawn came up on the next day, and it struck the plant so that it withered.

And it came to pass, when the sun rose, that God appointed a scorching east wind; and the sun beat upon the head of Jonah, so that he fainted, and he asked for his soul to die, and said, “It is better for me to die than to live.”
And God said to Jonah, “Is it right for you to be so angry about the plant?” And he said, “It is right for me to be angry, even to death.”
And the LORD said, You have had pity on the plant, for which you did not labor, nor did you make it grow, which came up in a night and perished in a night.
And should not I spare Nineveh, that great city, in which are more than twelve times ten thousand persons who do not know their right hand from their left, and also much cattle?
